Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Microscopic ID tags using optical wireless integrated circuit technologies
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a new class of intelligent, inexpensive, and nearly invisible identification tags. There is a compelling economic and societal need to connect physical objects to the digital world online. For example, counterfeit products siphon revenue from legitimate companies and undermine quality control, sometimes in life-threatening ways. Approximately $1.8 trillion of counterfeit goods are sold annually, a number growing at 15% per year. The market for fake pharmaceutical drugs is $200 B, electronic chips and semiconductor products is $170 B, and jewelry $50 B. The proposed technology is a potentially powerful solution to this pressing problem, especially for objects that are difficult or impossible to label with radio frequency identification RFID tags due to the RFID’s large size, incompatible materials, or cost. This proposed tag would be the size of a speck when viewed by the naked eye. includes microelectronic components, jewelry, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, watches, and even bullets. <br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of a new class of ID tags that use optical wireless integrated circuit (OWiC) technologies. These devices combine silicon microelectronics with optical components to use light for power and communication. The technologies used to produce OWiCs have enabled integration of silicon electronics into remotely accessible packages as small as 100 µm x 100 µm x 10 µm. These hundred-micron-sized ID tags are: (i) effectively invisible; (ii) intelligent, with thousands of on-board transistors for secure authentication protocols; and (iii) integrated, with a built-in optical communication system made of photovoltaics/microLEDs. The cost to manufacture per tag is projected at less than a penny. These features give the ID tags the intelligence of a small computer to ensure security, a reasonable cost to encourage broad use, a small footprint, and a simple light-based interface for hand-held scanning.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of OWiC Technologies is to make the physical world ‘clickable’, i.e. to seamlessly link any physical object to relevant digital data. Such data can provide enormous value to stakeholders throughout the entire product life cycle, from supply chain tracking to maintenance records to customer engagement. Links on objects such as QR codes or RFID tags are growing exponentially, rendering the world as clickable as a webpage. However, these existing tags are too large/visually unappealing to be attached objects such as jewelry, machine parts, or semiconductor chips.

OWiC technologies is creating a revolutionary new class of microscopic ID tags called MicroLinks to meet this unmet need. A MicroLink tag is a miniaturized communications platform to securely, intelligently, and wirelessly connect the physical and digital worlds, all in a package the width of a human hair. It is powered and communicates with light, sending out a digital code to identify the object. 

With I-Corps funding, the team conducted over 150 Customer Discovery interviews with a broad cross-section of potential customers, partners, and related stakeholders. These interviews led the team to pivot from an initial focus on microLINK tags for product authentication and move instead to microLINKs for assisting in enterprise manufacturing, tracking, and maintenance. With this change, the team made excellent progress in attracting investment and identifying early customers and partners, including initial sales.

The I-Corps grant also funded the development of a full technology demonstration kit for the microLINK platform. This allowed the OWiC team to engage decision makers at major companies and get a product in their hands. This significantly de-risks the technology and allows OWiC to aggressively focus on product/market fit, a scalable business model, and scalable manufacturing.
